content: The Act titled "Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act" establishes protocols for national responses to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act mandates the development of protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals, including intentional releases. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must consult with states, public health officers, and attorneys general in this process. After the enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in consultation with the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board, will develop a list of chemicals known to cause death or serious health effects. Protocols specific to each hazardous agent will be developed under this Act. The Secretary will develop protocols for hazardous agents, with specific provisions for each agent, prioritizing within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will establish priorities for hazardous agents within 45 days of the Act's enactment and begin developing protocols promptly after. The goal is to complete development for each protocol within 45 days of starting. The Secretary must develop protocols promptly after establishing priorities for hazardous agents, aiming to complete each protocol within 45 days. The provisions of the protocol should ensure uniform application in public health emergencies involving the hazardous agent. The protocol under subsection (a) must ensure uniform application in public health emergencies involving the hazardous agent and coordinate with emergency response personnel to provide medically appropriate information promptly to individuals present at sites. In public health emergencies, protocols must be followed to ensure uniformity and coordination with emergency response personnel. This includes providing timely medical information to individuals at affected sites, testing and treating affected individuals, decontaminating sites, and differentiating responses based on whether the release of the hazardous agent was accidental or intentional. The Secretary shall periodically review and revise protocols for responding to public health emergencies, including decontamination of sites and differentiating responses based on the nature of the hazardous agent release. Development exemptions may be granted if existing protocols meet requirements, with a report to Congress listing exempt hazardous agents. The Secretary will provide a list of hazardous agents for which development exemptions have been granted, without affecting the review and revision requirements. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 for carrying out this section.
